question: I want my fucking Zippo now! Walter starts yanking at his hair.
answer: Walter, that is a behavior...

question: Fuck you!
answer: And you are making a choice. Her cell phone rings... Hold on...Hello?

question: God no. So are all these busy young wedding helpers staying at the house? Because after eight months of constantly revolving cell mates and crazy people...
answer: You weren't in a cell, Kym...

question: ...AND groups groups GROUPS...
answer: ...And nobody was crazy, nobody was in a rubber room...

question: It's a nightmare so bad it's in German.
answer: Rachel must be totally freaking out. Is she too tense?...

question: She's a wigwam!
answer: ...Is she eating? Or are all her latent food issues rearing their heads? Is she hoarding Snickers and Cool Whip under the bed like in high school? She never did put that one to sleep.

question: I don't think that that's a problem for her.
answer: No offense, Dad, but you never thought that was a problem for her. I'm kidding. It'll be great to see her. Foodies are the worst, though. They never get it together. There were six of them on my floor in the hospital and you could never get into the bathroom. They would cry at the chocolate pudding and one of

question: You'll see her and Andrew at the rehearsal dinner tonight.
answer: Can we stop at the 7/11 please? I feel nauseous. I need something to drink.

question: You should prescribe something soothing for Emma. Like Vicodin.
answer: I will have my PhD. in a year and a half. And psychologists don't get prescription pads, right Kym?

question: They do in Guam.
answer: Would you please put that out? Emma designed this dress and there's forty-seven yards of it and I'll go up like the Hindenburg. Kym takes a last drag even though she's down to the filter, then flushes the butt down the toilet in the tiny bathroom.

question: Non-specified Eating Disorder.
answer: ...they were constantly doing leg lifts under the sheets.

question: Angela Paylin is coming to the wedding.
answer: I ate so much cookie dough and did so many whip-its with Angela Paylin.

question: I know. And she confessed to you her secret Elvis Stoyko fantasy. I spied on you.
answer: Oh my god...

question: In her fantasy, she was wearing her hair up and very serious, responsible eyeglasses, because she was a world renowned judge at the Winter Olympics for Men's Figure Skating. And Elvis Stoyko was skating in the finals to "Could It Be Magic" for the gold medal. And just when Barry Manilow is singing "Now/ Now/ Now and hold on fast..." there's this electric connection between them and he stops in the middle of his triple lutz...axel...
answer: And he skates over to the judges table, all panting and sweaty, with his spangly Neil Diamond shirt open to the chest...

question: There is silence as he stops in front of her, their eyes lock, and he reaches for her hand... and Angela takes it!
answer: To the roar of the crowd and the shock of the Olympic judges!

question: Ooo! Can I see?! Okay, okay! Kymmie, what can I make you?
answer: Actually there's a meeting I have to make. And I have to pee in a cup. And register as a general biohazard.

question: I'll drive you.
answer: Just tell me which car I should take. Paul doesn't say anything. Carol floats to Paul's side. Which car?

question: Would you do me a favor, Kymmie...?
answer: I have a license...

question: You wouldn't believe my insurance. And I'm not... that comfortable. Could we figure something else out?
answer: Ow! Hello? Hello? Hi. I'm here to pee in a cup. Okay. I'm trying to get to a meeting. I know that. Piss! Shit! COCKSUCKER!

question: Carol, she's here!
answer: Where did you think I was?

question: Hey.
answer: Hi there. Well, that was so wrong --

question: Gee, thanks!
answer: No, believe me, that was so lovely, LOVELY! But in the program -- as you know -- and we just heard earlier today in fact --

question: It is kind of lurid, isn't it? The best man and the maid of honor... furtively slipping off to the coal bin to have it off while the rest of the wedding party labors away at preparations for the big event.
answer: I thought...isn't Emma going to be playing that role?

question: What?
answer: "Maid of Honor"?

question: Oh.
answer: I think I heard that was the plan.

question: You wore a lilac sweater with a cat face on it on the cover of Seventeen Magazine when I was at Fat Camp.
answer: Sure, but I got paid for that and I was on horse tranquilizers. So why aren't I the Maid of Honor? Why is Emma the Maid of Honor?

question: Because.
answer: What does that mean?

question: I wasn't entirely sure when you were coming or even if you'd make it. I wasn't sure if you'd have time for a fitting.
answer: Bullshit. It's a sari. You take a bolt of cloth and wrap it around you. Jesus Christ I've been home one day and I can't get a straight answer out of anybody.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: I'm talking about Dad offering me food every ten seconds...

question: Dad offers Irish Hunger Strikers food every ten seconds.
answer: No. He has to know where I am and what I'm doing all the time because he has never resolved his own trust issues.

question: Fine. The crown is yours, First Runner Up.
answer: Thank you, Emma. No, thank you.

question: It's not about you.
answer: It's about sisterhood.

question: Hooray for sisterhood.
answer: Sisterhood conquers all.

question: Huge liability.
answer: You're a lawyer?

question: Was. For about five minutes.
answer: Say something legal.

question: Tort.
answer: So what do you do now?

question: I help Sidney out with the business side of his stuff.
answer: Sweet.

question: Wow. We were wondering if you got the dates scrambled.
answer: Yes, everything is absolutely fine now.

question: Thank god. What a relief! Now the party can really get started. So Mom, you look great.
answer: Darling, can you smoke that in here?

question: It's a private party, Mom. How's grandma? Still surly and irascible?
answer: Oh, you know how she is. She sends her love.

question: Great. Same.
answer: Honey, you should really put that out. It's not right. You know that.

question: Commence embarrassing story.
answer: That wasn't it?

question: Rach, do you remember the time I was teaching you to drive in the Wagoneer and you sideswiped that taxi driver and knocked off his side mirror?
answer: I have no memory of that whatsoever.

question: Do you remember trying to outrun him and leading him on a high speed chase across 96th street?
answer: Gotta say no.

question: Nice apology.
answer: What?

question: Nice apology.
answer: I was toasting you and I was making amends. It's one of the Steps. It's important.

question: I know what the Steps are. I learned them in school, and I've visited you in various facilities, Kym.
answer: Oh, god. Dad?

question: Amends. Noun. Often followed by 'for'. Offset a disability or frustration by development in another direction. Rachel blinks at her sister.
answer: Yes?

question: You've never said anything to me, that's remotely apologetic. Yet, all of a sudden, at my wedding dinner, in front of everybody, you decide to grace us all with your development?
answer: Christ. I just got here. Carol hands Kym a slice of watermelon.

question: Are you kidding? The two of you are like a double helix of crises. In the language of psychology one could say you both suffer from acute boundary issues.
answer: Rachel! It's nice that you're getting your Ph.D--

question: --Oh god--
answer: --but don't be patronizing. It's ugly. It doesn't become you.

question: How come she gets to spout off about paternal issues, but god forbid I should even reference the "boundary thing," even though I actually know what I'm talking about?
answer: Hello? By the way? I'm not in crisis. I haven't been in crisis for a year.

question: You just got out of rehab!
answer: Why is this so difficult for you people to understand? It's like you're not happy unless I'm in some kind of desperate situation. You have no idea what to do with me unless I'm desperate. God. Why am I the only one who's willing to say this stuff?

question: Oh, poor you. You're so much more evolved in your suffering. You know what? Your suffering is not the most important thing in the world to everybody!
answer: What?

question: You're pretty everything! He mushes her face and kisses her cheek. Then he mushes Carol's face.
answer: Holy cow. What a day. I think I've aged. I mean it. ) Would you mind if I went to bed, darling?

question: Of course not. I'll be up, Carol. I'm just going to load the dishwasher.
answer: Let me help, it'll be quicker.

question: Don't mess with the King.
answer: Okay,okay. Hands in the air, Carol leaves the room.

question: I've never been so tired in my life. Dad?
answer: Yes, sweetheart?

question: I hope it's okay, I told Mom at dinner. About the baby.
answer: Of course, lamb chop. I'm so happy! I'm going to be a grandpa!

question: I wish Ethan were here.
answer: I know, sweetheart. Me too.

question: That was such a set-up.
answer: She probably didn't realize she was doing it.

question: Ha! She's such an operator. Now I'm the bad guy again. Or still.
answer: They're lucky to have you.

question: Thank you! Otherwise they'd have to pay attention to their own suspicious lives. Nobody actually wants me to actually change, you know. What would they obsess about? I'm like a blessing.
answer: No argument from me.

question: Dad had an actual "Blueprint for Rehabilitative Success" at my last intervention. On graph paper. He goes all out with the response, my dad.
answer: Not unlike this great nation in which we live.

question: Meanwhile an ex-heterosexual ex-boy friend of mine actually rang the door once and tells my mother, "Kym is sitting in her apartment? With the shades drawn? Doing all this heroin and cocaine? And I think she's going to, like, die?" And Mom smiles and says "Thank you" like he was speaking in Sanskrit.
answer: You can't actually speak in Sanskrit.

question: Exactly! I nodded out into the poached salmon at Dad's wedding two years ago and he told Carol he thought it was jet lag.
answer: I did that in soup once. It made such a mess.

question: Look how exquisite this is. I can't borrow this. What do you carry in here? A vital organ? A tiny spleen?
answer: Isn't it divine? It was grandma's. She sends her love.

question: I love the color. It's oyster.
answer: You must promise me you'll stay healthy now, Rachel. You'll eat properly and get a lot of rest?

question: Yes, Mom.
answer: How are things going at the house? How's Sidney?

question: Fine.
answer: And his friend? What's his name?

question: Kieran.
answer: He seems to be a big hit. Is your sister behaving herself?

question: I'm not exactly sure what that means.
answer: Well, she needs a lot of acknowledgement.

question: You think?
answer: Stop. It can't be easy. Everybody knowing her troubles.

question: Mom, she's sold syndication rights to her troubles.
answer: Stop.

question: Mom, does it bother you at all, Carol doing so much wedding stuff?
answer: Not at all, darling, I'm thrilled to be providing the flowers. You know how much that means to me. They're going to be exquisite!

question: Yes, I'm sure, and that's so great and so you, but you can do whatever else you want, you know. I'd love it.
answer: Thank you, my sweetheart. I just know I'd be one of those wedding mothers who goes completely insane about the hors d'oeuvres. Andrew says I shouldn't be allowed near a shrimp puff.

question: Huh.
answer: There are so many other people for you to worry about.

question: You're right.
answer: But this is going to be the most beautiful wedding ever. And I hope your sister has a wonderful time too...Anyway I'm going to be a grandmother! Hooray!

question: Hooray!
answer: I'm so excited. I have always wanted to be a grandmother. Even when I was thirty. Here. This ring was grandma's and she wanted you to have it.

question: Is she dead?
answer: Rachel.

question: It's beautiful. Thanks, Mom. I hope it's a boy.
answer: As long as it's healthy. Try the ring on. Rachel does. You've always had the most beautiful hands.

question: Your hand is on the turf.
answer: What turf?

question: The turf. The table.
answer: So?

question: So we have to do it over now. It was your shot and you get to do it over.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Don't tell me you didn't know having one hand on the turf makes the play null.
answer: Null. Maybe we should just play Pinball.

question: Sometimes playing next to each other is easier than playing together.
answer: Who told you that?

question: My mom. She runs a pre-school.
answer: What's Hawaii like?

question: You've never been?
answer: Uh uh.

question: It's beautiful. I've got a nice place. My horse lives there.
answer: Most people say "my girlfriend lives there" or "my wife lives there."

question: I live there and so does my horse. He's very possessive. We're working through it.
answer: Have you had him a long time?

question: Yes. I may be a degenerate dope fiend but I love my horse. I don't have a wife or a girlfriend and I've been clean almost seven years. You could just ask, you know. Your sister doesn't ask direct questions either. She's incredibly cryptic.
answer: That's a shrink thing, not a genetic thing. We were in the park. I was sixteen and I was...I had taken all these Percoset. I was unbelievably high.

question: I am.
answer: Where are you putting me?

question: I was thinking of putting you with Cookie Puss and the Chicago cousins because they always get really drunk and need wrangling.
answer: Can someone else do it? I was planning on enjoying myself.

question: You're the only one they're afraid of.
answer: Still? God.

question: Still? God.
answer: We can move Grandma Rose and her companion. That's actually a great idea.

question: That's all I need. Another reason for Grandma Rose to hate me.
answer: She doesn't hate you.

question: She's still mad about that thing at the Rite Aid.
answer: Nonsense!

question: Dad, can I show you something in the kitchen?
answer: Rachel, what is this behavior?

question: I would just like to have a day please.
answer: Have all the days you want. Nobody is taking your day.

question: Then why are you defending her?
answer: Defending her from what? Darling, look, no one's defending any body...

question: Why are you protecting her?
answer: I don't want her to feel like we don't want her.

question: Sometimes I don't want her. It's my fucking wedding, don't you get it? I want my table to be perfect. Paul kisses her on the forehead.
answer: Stop it. She's your sister. Okay. Dishes? I'm going to load the dishwasher.

question: You see Paul, I think your problem lies in lid placement.
answer: Rachel, you're out of the will.

question: Observe.
answer: Clean out this machine please, boy. So I can break out the whup-ass.

question: You know one of the early signs of senile dementia is an obsessive need to organize.
answer: Rachel, go fetch me my dart gun.

question: I find it touching but ultimately sad when the warriors of yesteryear are reluctant to lay down their plastic containers from Zabar's and retire gracefully.
answer: Kieran, how's my time?

question: Mom is handling the flowers?
answer: Well, she's growing them and choosing them - but they are being delivered by her people.

question: Got it. Wow. Nurturing and growing things from the soil. Textbook, right?
answer: Kym. Can we talk about the candles for a minute? Because --

question: Yeah, exactly! Candles and rice paper -- all lit up during the ceremony. It's a way of honoring Ethan, Ethan's... spirit, you know? It will look really nice too, mainly. Millions of little candles all over the place, and one huge rice paper candle - representing Ethan - glowing near the couple. That would be you and Sidney.
answer: Oh my god, no. Don't. Just don't. That would kill Dad. And Mom. And me. And everybody. Please, Kym, please please please don't do that.

question: Geez. It was an IDEA. Lighten up, okay? They do that in Japan or India or someplace, okay?
answer: Just drop it, sweetie, okay? Please?

question: Oh my god - fine! Done! It was nothing, okay. It was just an idea. Are you getting a manicure?
answer: You don't remember me, do you?

question: Nooooo.....
answer: Rick James' limousine.

question: Oh. My. God.
answer: Yeah.

question: I meant to come back. I swear. I even had...Oh god, what was it?
answer: Peanut M&M's and Carbona cleaning fluid.

question: God is punishing me.
answer: No, he's blessing me. It's cool

question: So, how are ya?
answer: I'm okay. You remember we were in the hospital together, right?

question: We were...at Milestones?
answer: No. I didn't go to Milestones. I didn't have the coverage. We were on the same floor at Loeb House. That was before you went to Milestones.

question: Where did you go after that?
answer: My parents' house. Unemployment. It's all about the coverage, right? I can't believe I'm seeing you again.

question: I know. It's so weird.
answer: Listen. Do you remember that exercise where we all had to write down experiences and pass them anonymously to another person?

question: "The Human Mirror
answer: I got yours. You drew poodles in the margins. I know it's supposed to be anonymous and everything, but you were so brave. The way your uncle abused you and your sister, and how it led to your sister's anorexia, and how you stayed up nights when she was down to fifty pounds holding a mirror to her face to make sure she was breathing. I'll never forget reading that, I swear to God. I found it so profoundly inspirational that you could be there for her during your own incredible ordeal. I thank God that you came in here today. I never thought I'd ever have the chance to thank you. It was your strength that gave me the courage to confront my own abuse and help me turn my life around. Rachel slams down her magazine and leaves the salon. Kym runs after her. Both girls have foils in their hair.

question: Would you stop?
answer: Don't touch me.

question: Don't you think his perspective might be a little skewed?
answer: I never had anorexia. You sure as hell didn't watch over me while I was sleeping and WE DON'T HAVE A

question: --That we know of!-- Ew!... Wait... Rachel yanks open the car door, jumps in. I wasn't hurting anybody. No one got hurt, Rach. Rachel slams the car door shut.
answer: I'm hurt! I hate her.

question: I'm hurt! I hate her.
answer: You don't hate her.

question: Don't tell me what I don't hate. I hate, hate the lies. She lied in rehab.
answer: What do you mean she lied?

question: She lied to the people who were working with her. Who were trying to help her. She lies to everybody.
answer: Where is she now?

question: Where am I now, Dad?
answer: Thank god. In here. Kym comes stomping in. Her foils are still intact.

question: Kym, what is your sister saying? Did you say you were sexually molested?
answer: Oh Jesus Christ. Not by you! It was a long time ago!

question: Were you?
answer: No!

question: Why in god's name would you say something like that?
answer: It was anonymous! It seemed like a good idea at the time. The three on the couch are stunned for a moment.

question: It was an accident.
answer: Yes! I was stoned out of my mind! Jesus Christ, who do I have to be now? Mother Theresa? Did I use up all the love I'm allowed for this lifetime because I killed our little brother?

question: No, it was an accident!
answer: I'm sorry! I'm sorry, okay? I'm sorry!

question: It was an accident. Kym, her hair still in foils, rushes out of the house.
answer: Hello?

question: Hello Abby. It's Paul.
answer: Hello Paul.

question: Is Kym with you?
answer: No. Why? Did she go somewhere?

question: She left the house about an hour ago.
answer: To a meeting?

question: She and Rachel had an argument.
answer: Oh, dear. The night before her wedding? What was it about?

question: Look, Abby, it doesn't matter. She left the house. She took the car.
answer: What was the argument about?

question: I don't know. They were both getting their hair done...
answer: You don't know? Well what were they saying?

question: For god's sake Abby! I'm trying to figure out where she went before I call the police!
answer: Well, last time you called the police looking for her she was upstairs, asleep in the guest room.

question: She wasn't asleep, she was unconscious! And I'm glad I called the police because it took twenty minutes to wake her up and at least something was being done!
answer: Paul, I'm trying to help.

question: You're trying to dismiss everything!
answer: She's not a criminal!

question: You're disregarding everything I'm saying, and this failure to listen, failure to understand what is right in front of you is exactly why you will never be able...
answer: Paul!...

question: ...To help her!
answer: Maybe that's not what she needs all the time...

question: What?
answer: I mean..I mean maybe she needs us --

question: -- Maybe she needs someone to be watchful and present and in her life!
answer: -- To trust her --

question: She could hurt herself! She could be lying dead in a ditch somewhere!
answer: All right! All right! Stop it!

question: If you hear anything, can I count on you to please call me?
answer: Can you count on me?... Yes Paul, you can count on me to call if I hear anything.

question: Okay, then.
answer: Goodbye.

question: Ahhh....
answer: You should call your father.

question: In a minute. I need a glass of water.
answer: I've made some tea. Here darling. Sit down. You look upset.

question: When will Andrew be back?
answer: Not too late. He's at a dinner. I spoke to grandma today. She sends her love. Is everything all right with the wedding?

question: Yes.
answer: Good.

question: Dad was loading the dishwasher...
answer: Mmm hmmm...

question: And I handed him Ethan's bowl with the trains on it by accident. Why did you leave me in charge of him? Abby stops. You knew. All of you knew. People told you. I was a junkie.
answer: You were sick.

question: You know what I was. It's not like there weren't any clues. I stayed in my room for days. I passed out all the time. Where were you, Mom! What were you thinking? Why did you leave me? Why did you leave me in charge of him? Abby closes her fists and beats Kym with all her strength.
answer: You weren't supposed to kill him! You weren't supposed to kill him! Kym curls up protectively and Abby suddenly stops.

question: Mom? Mom?
answer: Get away!

question: Are you all right? They meet at the circular driveway.
answer: I hit Mom.

question: Oh my god is she...
answer: Not with the car. I have to get dressed.

question: Look at you! You need to get to a hospital!
answer: Dad! I'm fine.

question: Holy shit. She just showed up. Yes. Thank you. Do you need a doctor?
answer: You sent out the cavalry?

question: For your dad. Mostly for your dad.
answer: I have to get ready. I have to get dressed.

question: Aaaah! Fuck! She is dressed in her Sari and huge gold earrings and looks beautiful, despite a lack of sleep. Seeing her bashed up sister framed in the doorway, Rachel fights tears. She loses.
answer: I hit Mom.

question: With the car?
answer: No. No.

question: You hit Mom? You hit our mother?
answer: Okay.

question: I got it. Can you do this? Okay.
answer: Excuse me.

question: Sorry...I'm not sure... That sucked. Ouch. The girl laughs and runs off. Hi. Where's Mom?
answer: Taking a break.

question: How can you take a break from your own daughter's wedding?
answer: Mom doesn't actually participate in things.

question: And anyway, she hasn't even done anything all day.
answer: I was thinking about getting her a cat. Cats are really annoying. At some point you have to deal with them, right? Or they starve to death and piss on your sheets.

question: I've been looking for you all over the place. I'm in here. All right.
answer: You're leaving?

question: Darling, I'm exhausted. I had such a marvelous time. Those dancers were so beautiful. But weddings are really for young people.
answer: You could make a little scene.

question: It's the mother of all fund raisers at American. I thought I mentioned it. We're going to stay on about a week - there are lots of meetings. I thought since you two are going away soon... ...and I'm sure you don't want any grown ups around checking up on you...Will you still be here when I get back? Kym doesn't say anything.
answer: What about our post-nuptial wedding gossip reconnaissance, Mom?

question: Well, can you come by early?
answer: Um...

question: Of course you don't want to do that. It's your wedding night. You don't want to get up early. I have to get Andrew organized. He's hopeless. And we'll be back in a bit. It was such a lovely wedding, darling. She bends in for a kiss.
answer: Wait! I want my mother and my sister!

question: Rachel... Will you call me every day about...? She pats Rachel's tummy.
answer: Yes. Of course.

question: Hi Kym.
answer: Susanna has a public relations firm and she just lost one of her assistants.

question: Weddings. They're an epidemic. Your father gave me my start about a hundred years ago.
answer: No, no. Hardly. Well...

question: I've got it. Thanks, Dad. I'll be right back. Oof. You scared me.
answer: Making a break for it?

question: Yeah. I have to go. I was coming to find you.
answer: You don't have to slip away without making any noise, you know? I like noise.

question: I was coming to find you. My ride's outside.
answer: ...Okay...If you need anything...

question: If I need to post bond? Kieran hands Kym a folded piece of paper.
answer: No. If you ever need anything.

question: Thank you, Kieran.
answer: Maybe you'll come visit me in Hawaii?
